quote: Come in.
Commander, I just received word that    a Valerian transport has requested    permission to dock here at the    station.
Let me guess.  You're here to    recommend we deny their request.
The Valerians ran weapons-grade    dolamide to Cardassian forces during    the occupation of Bajor.
I'm aware of that...
I believe they're continuing to ship    weapons to the Cardassians... weapons    that could eventually be used to    attack Bajor.
I share your concern, Major.  But    unless we have proof to back up those    charges...
The proof is on the ship.  Let me    conduct a search and if I find any    dolamide, we can confiscate it.
I'm afraid it's not that simple.     Dolamide is used for power generators,    reactors, in short-range transports...
And for weapons.
Only if it's extremely pure.
So we're going to do nothing.
I didn't say that.  But we can't    just board their ship and start    tearing it apart.
Then what can we do?
You bring me evidence that the    Valerians are dealing in weapons-   grade dolamide and I promise you the    Federation will use every kind of    diplomatic pressure to stop them.
You think that'll work?
It will if the Valerians want to    keep trading with the Federation.
(still not totally     convinced)   All right, we'll try it your way.
Good.  Then you'll see to it that    the Valerian ship is cleared for    docking.
(still doesn't relish     the thought)   Yes, sir.
Chief, I have a subspace message for    you from your wife.  They've arrived    safely on Bajor.
Imagine, taking eleven bored    schoolkids on a visit to the grain    processing center at Lasuma.  I'm    glad it's not me.
Here's the information you wanted on    the captain of the Valerian ship.
Let me know if you find anything    else.
Sensors are reading elevated neutrino    levels at the wormhole... Something's    coming through...
On screen.
The wormhole opens and a KLINGON    BIRD OF PREY comes blasting through.
It's the Klingon vessel Toh'Kaht.
They're not due back for another    month.
Open hailing frequencies.
I'm reading a transporter signal.     Someone must have beamed off the    ship just as it exploded.
Mister O'Brien -- ?
Something's interfering with the    rematerialization process.
Lock onto him with our Transporter    signal.  Try boosting the annular    containment field.
I'm already there...
He's been hit by weapons fire.  It's    severe.  We've got to get him into    cryo-stasis.
Victory...
He's dead.

Station log, Stardate 46922.3.  We    have identified the dead Klingon --    his name was Hon-Tihl, First Officer    of the Toh'Kaht.  Why he died, and    the cause of his ship's destruction,    is still unknown.
I found tritanium alloy fragments in    his chest and upper arms.  If that    was all, we could have saved him.     But those weapon burns were too    severe.
Is there any way to identify the    kind of weapon used?
I'm running a microtissue analysis    right now.  We should have the results    in a couple of hours.
The Klingon said "victory" before he    died.  I wonder what he meant.
According to the Klingon high command,    the Toh'Kaht was in the gamma quadrant    on a routine bio-survey mission...
"Victory"... during a bio-survey... ?
As I recall the Toh'Kaht put in for    a maintenance check.
Ask around the station, see if you    can learn anything about this bio-   survey.
I'd like the two of you to take a    Runabout and try to find the    Toh'Kaht's mission recorder.  I want    to know what caused that ship to    explode.
Aye, Sir.
Lieutenant...
Yes...
You coming?
I'm sorry, I was... nevermind...
Dammit.  Not yet...
Deep Space Nine, this is Valerian    vessel Sherval Das.  We are entering    the Bajoran system, clear us for    docking.
Negative, Sherval Das.  There's going    to be a slight delay.
We are in need of maintenance.  It    has been a long journey.
I'm sure it has.  But we've got our    own problems.  You'll just have to    wait --
Stand by, Sherval Das.
I'd like an explanation.
I'm not finished running the    background check on their ship.
We agreed there'd be no delays in    the docking procedure --

They just visited Fahleena Three and    Mariah Four -- the same two stops    they used to make when they were    running dolamide to the Cardassians.     The last stop would be the    purification plant on Ultima Thule.
If I can place them there, we'll    know they're carrying weapons-grade    material.
Your ship is cleared for docking.
Thank you, Commander.  Sherval Das    out.
No delays...
Isn't it always the same old story?     I hear it day in, day out.  She takes    you for granted.  She doesn't    appreciate your... finer qualities.
The cut of your jib... The twist of    your tulamak...
The way you turn a phrase...       What does she want?
Two Pistres?  For all my compassion?       You call that a tip?  No wonder she    left you!  You piker!
Trouble, Quark?
Nothing I can't handle.
I heard you had some problems with    the Klingons the last time they came    through...
Spare me from beings who think pain    is pleasure.       In small doses, perhaps.  But the    Klingons?  They're rough on the    holosuites.  They break the furniture.
I'm still fixing the walls in    Holosuite Six.       I'm not saying they don't spend big.     I'm just saying by the time you figure    in the damage, I'm lucky to break    even.
They do tend toward bluster, don't    they?  Throwing their weight around.     Bragging...
This crew was worse than the last.     "Our glorious mission."  I asked    them, "what's so glorious about a    gamma quadrant bio-survey?"
And what did they say?
Crafty tonight, aren't we, Odo?     Looking for clues about the fate of    the Klingons.  If I tell you what I    heard, what do I get in return?
Chances are, what you heard won't    help.  So why should I give you    something for it?
Because otherwise, I heard nothing.
Those damaged holosuites.  Work crew    seven is probably doing the repairs,    am I right?
Yes...
Well, it looks as though I might    have to put in a priority request    for work crew seven.  The bulkheads    in security could use a little shoring    up.
They said they were coming back    through the wormhole with something    that would "make the enemies of the    Klingon Empire tremble."
Their exact words?
A direct quote.
You've been most helpful.
Don't let it get around.
Odo?
Doctor Bashir!  Doctor Bashir!
Welcome back, Constable.
How am I?
How do you feel?
Fine.
Good.       Because I've got no way to know.     Your body chemistry defies analysis.
I don't remember anything...
But, I'm back to normal?
Like I said -- you tell me.  I don't    know what caused it, and I couldn't    tell you if it'll happen again.     There's really nothing more I can do    here.
Then thank you for your time, Doctor.
Tell me Odo, do you share my concern    about this Valerian situation?
Concern?
I think you know what I mean.
Why don't you tell me and then you    can be sure I know.
Just don't be surprised if the uneasy    alliance on this station starts to    show a few cracks...
What "uneasy alliance"?
Commander Sisko and Kira.  Mark my    words, there's going to be trouble.
Exactly what are you basing all this    on, Doctor?
Very clever, Constable.    (a conspiratorial     nod)   You're probably right.  It's still    too early to commit oneself either    way.
Are you finished with me?
Unless you'd like to pour yourself    through my phoretic analyzer -- I'd    love to see the results.
Another time, perhaps.
I've got them!
Who?
The Valerians.  Their ship was at    the Ultima Thule station one week    ago.  That confirms it.  They're    definitely running dolamide.

So I've got an armed team ready to    board their vessel.  We confiscate    the material and send them back where    they came from.  Frankly, I'm half    tempted to take them to Bajor and    press charges.
By whose authority?
You're not going to do anything about    this?
I'm not.  And neither are you.
Commanded by a Federation officer.     Commanded by me.  Are you challenging    that, Major?
No, Sir...
Good...       Now is there anything else I can do    for you?
Short-range sensors are picking up    some debris.
Looks like duranium alloy.  Probably    pieces of the Klingon's secondary    hull.
It's possible their mission recorder    is somewhere in the debris.  The    magnetic field from the duranium    could be masking it.
Let's get a little closer...
Major Kira's been awfully aggressive    toward Commander Sisko lately...    about station policy.
An honest difference of opinion.
We're within a thousand meters...    Secondary hull fragments, pieces of    the bulkhead... Still no sign of the    recorder.
I'm taking us closer...
What if it's more than a difference    of opinion?  What if Kira thinks the    Bajorans don't need us on DS Nine?     It is their station.
That would be suicidal.  Without a    Federation presence Bajor would be    vulnerable again to the Cardassians.
That doesn't mean there aren't plenty    of misguided Bajorans who think they    can go it alone.

Isn't it always like that?  Bitterness    is the coin by which generosity is    repaid.       I once helped the Federation deliver    rain-inducing technology to Kelton    Four.  The end of the drought was    the end of contact.  Talk about fair    weather friends --
You've become quite friendly with    Major Kira, haven't you?
Have I... ?  Well, yes, I suppose I    have... if you say so...
Well, I wouldn't get too friendly    with the natives if I were you.     Remember where your loyalties lie.
Of course.  Benjamin and I have been    close for a long time.  Hand and    glove.  I'm on his side -- no question    about it.       That reminds me of the time we found    ourselves --
Good.  Because anyone against Sisko    is against me.
I'm picking up a weak subspace    transponder signal.
It's the mission recorder.
Constable...
Can I help you, Major?
You always manage to help me, Odo.     In fact, I'd say we work pretty well    together -- you and I.
Yes.  I suppose our relationship has    always been... cooperative.
Exactly.  And that's just what I    need right now -- your cooperation.

I'm convinced the Valerians have    dolamide on board.  But the evidence    is still circumstantial.  I need    solid proof.       I want you to slip past their security    systems and into their cargo bay.
I heard Commander Sisko was adamant    about not interfering with the    Valerian ship.  Has he changed his    mind?
Yes.
How odd.
Very well.  I'll keep the two of you    informed of my progress.
That's not necessary.  The Commander's    busy -- no sense in bothering him.
I can't fool you, Odo.
You wanted me to go behind Sisko's    back, didn't you?
Forget it.  It was a bad idea.
What if you had to choose sides?       Just remember who your friends are.

Personal log, Miles O'Brien.  Stardate    46923.1.  We've managed to retrieve    a portion of the Klingon Officer's    journal.  Of course, Major Kira heard    about it immediately.  She must have    spies everywhere.

I believe the Captain has gone insane.     He has executed two more crew members,    charging them with attempted mutiny.     Medical Officer Kee-Bhor came to my    quarters insisting the violence is    being caused by those telepathic    energy spheres we brought back from    Saltah'na.  Believing he's the    Captain's spy, I slit his throat.
I've seen enough.
There's more.
The Klingon's mission must have    failed... and that failure caused    problems on board...
I couldn't care less what happened    to a Klingon ship.
The Klingons might want to know.     Dax and I are setting up a data    interpolation to fill in what's    missing -- but it'll take some time...
The search itself is often reward    enough.       Benjamin, do you remember that wild    goose chase back on Elanu Four... ?
Fine.  Do whatever you have to do,    but don't bother me with it.
Here we are.  A Modela aperitif.     It's bright and sweet.       Much like yourself, Lieutenant.       I'll put it on your tab.
The bad flattery is on the house.
The two loveliest creatures on DS    Nine.  I must be living correctly to    be so... blessed.  What can I do for    you, Major?
Get lost.
As you wish...
How are you, Lieutenant?
You know what they say -- put the    shoe on the right foot first, but    put the left foot first into the    bathtub.
I understand.
But what I really meant was...       Are you happy?
That's not a question I get asked    too often.
Oh, but it should be.  In my opinion,    you're the most valuable officer on    this station.       May I... ?
Please.
Not bad.  For Quark.
It is good...
I couldn't imagine running this    station without you.
Are you trying to tell me something?
My disagreement with Sisko about the    Valerians is no secret.  You know    how he gets once he makes a decision.
Like talking to a stone.       I remember a time on Rochani Three...    We were cornered by a party of Kaleans    who were not at all happy to see us.     But Benjamin --
-- You told me that story this    morning.
Oh.       I suppose I did...
If you were to talk to Starfleet    Command... tell them how displeased    the Bajorans are with Sisko's handling    of this... I'm sure they'd listen to    you...
I was decorated on my very first    assignment.  The Admiral was a    Vulcan... So during the presentation    ceremony --

Dax.  We have to keep the Valerians    here.  Until we can search their    ship and confiscate the dolamide.     You've got to convince Starfleet --    it's for the good of Bajor and the    Federation.
I've been friends with Benjamin Sisko    for many years... In many ways, he's    like a son to me.  Or at least a    nephew...       Some kind of close relative anyway...
Listen to me, Jadzia...
I'm getting rid of Sisko... one way    or another.  Don't force me to get    rid of you as well.
Would you like to join us?
Let me go!
What did you hear?
Nothing!  Nothing at all!
Good.
Is this a Ferengi fashion I'm not    aware of?
Kira tried to tear my head off.  I    want to file charges.
Tell me about it.
I heard her plotting --
Go on.
She was trying to convince Dax to    take her side against Sisko.
Did Dax seem persuaded?
What difference does that make?  I    was attacked!
Answer the question.
I couldn't tell.  She was on the    fence.

Doesn't Kira's behavior seem a little    out of the ordinary?  And the    others... At the staff briefing Sisko    was bored -- as if he couldn't be    bothered about running the station.       And Bashir... since when is he so    concerned with station politics.
Don't look at me like that.  I'm    perfectly normal.
I suppose you are.       It's time I had a talk with Sisko.
Odo... wait!
Odo!  I want satisfaction.

We have lost the battle for decks    five through twelve.  The armory    remains in the hands of Captain Tel-   Peh, who demands my death.  But I    remain confident that I can gain    control of this ship.
Sisko... ?
First officer's mission journal...    day twenty-three...
Come in.
Where's Commander Sisko?
In his quarters.  Where he's safe.

I am weakened by my wounds.  I sense    my enemies are closing in. Still, I    was able to hide the thalmerite device    under a crossbeam near the reactor    core on deck twenty-six.  Rather    than be taken prisoner, I will blow    up this ship and transport to safety.     Perhaps medical officer Kee-Bhor was    right.  All our trouble began when    we opened those energy spheres.  All    I know is that Captain Tel-Peh must    die.       Journal closed.
It sounds like there was a power    struggle on board.  Some kind of    attempted takeover.
Management by mutiny.  That's standard    operating procedure on a Klingon    vessel.
But awfully unusual for a Federation-   run space station...
Don't worry, if Major Kira tries    anything we'll be ready.
When will the other log entries be    available?
At the current rate of processing --    at least seven more hours.  But the    computer's taking it one entry at a    time.  I'll set it up so you can    access as it goes.
Thank you, Chief.
Of course, Constable.  Don't the    Commander and I always try to make    you happy?
What are you doing here?
Chief O'Brien's orders.
Come in.
Commander...
Hello, Constable.  How are you today?
Concerned, Sir.
On such a fine afternoon?  How

Commander, I think something might    be wrong with --       some of us.  Ever since the Klingon    ship exploded, and their First Officer    beamed over... certain behaviors and    attitudes have been... abnormal.
There appears to have been a mutiny    on the Klingon ship.  I wouldn't go    so far as to say the same thing is    happening on DS Nine.  But I find    some disturbing parallels --
-- If something's bothering you,    Odo, tell it to Mister O'Brien.     That's what he's there for.
What do you think?
What is it?
It's a clock.  Fascinating, isn't    it?
It's not nice to keep a friend    waiting.
Did we have an appointment?
When have I ever had to stand on    ceremony with you, Odo?
I need your help.       I just took care of the Valerians.
What do you mean?
I locked down the docking clamps.     That ship isn't leaving until I say    it is.       O'Brien will need at least a day to    do anything about it.       By then, it won't matter.
You're going after Sisko.
And O'Brien.  Either we get a more    reasonable commander from Starfleet --    somebody we can control -- or we go    it alone.

With me running this place, you'll    be able to do what needs to be done.     If you want to toss Quark out on his    ears -- toss him out.  If you want    to proclaim martial law on the    Promenade -- proclaim it.  This    station will be yours to protect --    with no interference.
What's your plan?
Odo, I trust you more than anyone on    this station.  Because you can't be    corrupted.       But this is a dangerous time.  I    can't take any chances, even with    you.
When the moment comes, you'll know    it.  I'll be counting on you.
Computer, open a channel to Starfleet    Headquarters.
Subspace communication to Federation    territories is currently unavailable.
Why?
By authority of Major Kira.
Open a channel to the Bajoran Council.
Communication to Bajor is currently    unavailable.
By authority of Chief O'Brien?
That is correct.
Computer, are you finished    reconstructing the journal of the    Klingon First officer.
Data interpolation is complete.
On screen.
Computer...       Scan the journal for mention of    contact with any alien race.
One entry found.
Play it.

First Officer's journal, day twenty-   two.  Our exploration of the fifth    planet has turned out to be a waste    of time.  This world is not worthy    of a Klingon colony.  All we found    was a collection of energy spheres    which possessed some type of    telepathic archive.  The spheres    described an ancient power struggle    that destroyed a race called the    Saltah'na.
We will forward these results to our    science divisions.
Kira has already locked down the    Valerian ship.  And she's diverted    half the station's systems to her    control.
Since when?
An hour ago.  I've heard some    disturbing rumors from our people on    the Promenade.       I think she's going to make an attempt    on your life.
I want you to arrest them.  Kira and    every Bajoran officer on this station.     I want the names of every sympathizer --
-- That's not a good idea, sir.     There are a lot more of them than    there are of us.  If we tip our hand,    it could work against us.
What can we do?
Leave the station.
Never.  Get me a phaser.  I'll get    rid of Kira.
Hear me out, sir... We leave the    station.  Raise a Federation attack    force.  And return.       And on that day we'll get rid of all    your enemies.
How do we proceed?
I need a few more hours to free up    the Valerian ship.  I've already    talked to their Captain.  He's more    than happy to take us back to    Federation space.
Call me as soon as you're ready...
It'll take effect in two minutes.     Plenty of time for --
-- For you to get a good night's    sleep.
Thank you, Doctor.
Chronic insomnia.  I think it's    hormonal.       So how are you?
I take it you've completed your    autopsy of the Klingon.
Of course.       You know, Odo, events have been moving    rapidly since our last conversation.     I'd advise you to choose sides or    risk finding yourself without any    friends at all.
The Klingon, Doctor, what did you    find?
He's still dead, if that's what you    mean.
I don't have time for jokes.
Your findings could determine who    controls this station.
How?
All in good time... First, tell me    about the Klingon...
I found nothing very unusual.  The    columnar cells in his brain stem...    the membrane permeability was off...
What could cause that?
Any number of things.
Could it have something to do with    telepathy?  The Klingons were studying    the telepathic archives of an ancient    race.
If those archives were contained    within a self-sustaining energy    matrix, it could explain the changes    in the Klingon's brain.
Could that energy matrix have somehow    caused them to re-enact the power    struggle that destroyed the    Saltah'nans.
Possibly.  What are you getting at?
Doctor, I believe the Klingon brought    the matrix with him... and everyone    in Ops was affected except me...    without a humanoid brain, my system    rejected it.
An interesting theory, Constable...    but I'm certainly not behaving out    of the ordinary.
Of course not.       But what if you and I are the only    two who aren't affected.
I see... and you think we can use    that to our advantage.
Exactly.
Tell me your plan.
The first thing we have to do is    figure out how to remove the field    from everyone affected.
But then we'd lose our advantage.
Would you rather someone blew up the    station?
I see your point.
The power to control the energy matrix    is the power to control this station.
If I could determine the natural    resonance frequencies of the field,    I might be able to generate an    interference signal of some kind    which could force it out.
Do it.  I promise, Doctor, you won't    regret it.
This reminds me of a game I used to    play... It had a maze... What was it    called?
I'm through level two.  See if you    can isolate the security blocks on    three.
The Winter Garden...
Lieutenant.
Oh.  I'm sorry.  I must have been    drifting.
Try drifting over here when you get    the chance.
What's taking so long, O'Brien?
Almost there, Sir.  We've got one    more level of security lockouts to    break through and the Valerian ship    will be ready to go.
Commander, I have the report you    asked for on those weapon scanners.
Give it to Mister O'Brien.
I really think you should see this,    sir.
Dax to Kira!
Is it Kira?!
Did Kira put you up to this?
No...
I want the truth.
Is that clear?
Let's see how this works...
Put it down... Sir...
Take them.
You were supposed to deactivate the    transporter!
I forgot...
Damn it.  Kira must have set up a    force field to keep us from beaming    onto the Valerian ship.  The    Transporter rerouted us here.
We've got to get to that ship.
Odo's our only chance.  He may be    able to override the field.
You're sure we can trust him?
I don't see where we have any choice.
Sisko to Odo...
Odo here.
Kira has moved against us.  She has    Dax on her side... We need your help,    Constable.  You've got to clear us a    path to the Valerian ship.
Take Crossover Bridge One to the    Cargo Bay entrance into Docking Port    Four.  I'll keep it open for you.
Right.  Sisko out.
Leave your combadge here.
Don't look so worried, Chief.  She    hasn't beaten us yet.
Yes, Sir.
They're still in the Airlock Six    Corridor...
What could they be doing in there?
Maybe they've given up.

Sisko would rather die... which is    fine with me.    (a beat, then Kira     smiles as she figures     it out)   They must have taken off their    combadges.  That's all right.  They    won't get far.
Somebody's taking out our    forcefields...
Whoever it is knows how to override    the security codes.
Kira to Odo.
Go ahead, Major.
Whose side are you on, Constable?
Yours, of course.
Really?  Then why are you helping    Sisko escape?
On the contrary.  You'll find him    trapped in Cargo Bay Four.  Consider    it my gift to you.
My apologies.  We'll see you there.     Kira out.
Well done... you certainly fooled    her.
Doctor, we're running out of time.

(attention focused on     his console)   I'm just about done.  I've set up an    ionic interference signal in Cargo    Bay Four.  It's calibrated to lock    onto the resonance frequencies of    the telepathic field and drive it    out of those affected.
What will happen to it then?
It'll remain suspended as long as    the interference is in effect.
That's all I need to know.  Let's    go.
What's wrong?
It won't open.
It's completely locked down.     Someone's activated a level five    security protocol.
There's only one person on this    station besides yourself who has    that kind of access.
Odo!
Relax, Commander...
... he'll be here any minute.
So... this is where it all ends.
For you.

You know what disturbs me?  The    ingratitude.  I offered you my help...    my kindness... my leadership... and    how do you repay me?  With betrayal...    But you won't get rid of me so easily.     You see, unlike you, I understand    history.  Time will be my greatest    ally.       My name will blaze like a comet across    the stars long after your petty    treacheries are forgotten.
But you won't be here to see it.
Major, wait...
I'm glad you two could make it.
Computer!  Execute Odo One!
Constable... ?
Everyone grab hold of something.
Welcome back...
Commander's log; Stardate 46924.5.     With nothing to contain it, the    telepathic matrix has dispersed in    space.
Meanwhile I'm happy to report    everything and everyone aboard DS    Nine has returned to normal.
Come in.
Did you really build that thing?
Apparently so.
Why?
I have no idea.
Major?
I know that none of us were really    responsible for our actions... but I    still feel like I owe you an apology.
For attempted mutiny.
Well... yes.
I think we'll let it go... this time.
